information.title: Definition
information.description: Directive Principles of State Policy are guidelines or principles given to the central and state governments of India, to be kept in mind while framing laws and policies. These principles aim to ensure social and economic justice for all citizens.

information.title: Nature
information.description: Unlike Fundamental Rights, Directive Principles are not enforceable by law. However, they are considered fundamental in the governance of the country and it is the duty of the State to apply these principles in making laws.

information.title: Social Justice
information.description: Several Directive Principles aim to promote social justice. These include promoting the welfare of the people, securing a social order for the promotion of welfare of the people, and minimizing inequalities in income, status, facilities, and opportunities.

information.title: Economic Justice
information.description: Directive Principles also focus on economic justice. They direct the state to secure the right to work, to education, and to public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness, and disablement. They also aim to secure just and humane conditions of work.

information.title: Equal Justice
information.description: The Directive Principles emphasize equal justice and free legal aid. They direct the State to promote equal justice and to provide free legal aid to ensure that opportunities for securing justice are not denied to any citizen by reason of economic or other disabilities.

information.title: International Peace
information.description: The Directive Principles also guide India's foreign policy. They direct the State to promote international peace and security, maintain just and honorable relations between nations, foster respect for international law and treaty obligations, and encourage settlement of international disputes by arbitration.

information.title: Uniform Civil Code
information.description: One of the Directive Principles is to secure for citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India. This aims to replace personal laws based on the scriptures and customs of each major religious community in India with a common set of rules governing every citizen.
